channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: 'Fascist' pick prompts soccer club flap
item.description: It was announced a few hours before April Fool's Day, but the appointment of one of the most controversial characters in European football is no laughing matter for one English Premier League soccer club.

item.title: Shock on court at horror fracture
item.description: University of Louisville spokesman Kenny Klein discusses Kevin Ware's leg injury during a recent NCAA basketball game.

item.title: Tennis: 'Brutal' win makes Murray No. 2
item.description: When Andy Murray first won the Miami Masters in 2009, it set him on course for a career-high ranking of No. 2 in the world later that year.

item.title: Bolt wins race on Copacabana beach
item.description: Sprint star Usain Bolt gave sports fans a taste of what to expect at the 2016 Rio Olympics when he won an exhibition race on Copacabana beach on Sunday.

item.title: Generations X, Y start to rule politics
item.description: The changes that we are seeing in public attitudes about homosexuality are just the tip of the political iceberg. As Bob Dylan once sang, performing to the Baby Boom generation when it was challenging the prevailing political orthodoxies, "something is happening here. But you don't know what it is. Do you, Mister Jones?"

item.title: Gay rights opponents' last argument
item.description: Paul Waldman says it's ridiculous for those who oppose gay marriage to say that it may adversely affect straight marriage.

item.title: Pope's gestures strike fire in hearts
item.description: Steven Avella says Pope Francis has used bold gestures to alert the world that changes are to come.

item.title: Gay player in NFL not a distraction
item.description: NFL punter Chris Kluwe says it isn't right that we can't accept people for who they are.

item.title: South Korea warns North of 'strong response' to attack
item.description: South Korea's president warns North Korea any provocative moves will be met with "a strong response" as the U.S. deploys stealth fighter jets in the tense region.

item.title: U.S. flies stealth fighters over S. Korea
item.description: The United States deploys stealth fighter jets to South Korea as part of ongoing joint military exercises between the two countries, a senior U.S. defense official says.

item.title: How far can N. Korean missiles go?
item.description: Patricia Wu reviews North Korea's weapons and the distances they can travel.

item.title: Annihilation threat 'normal' for S. Korea
item.description: As winter recedes, winds whip through downtown Seoul and chill the crowds of commuters on their way home. The sun is dropping and the pale golden light streams between tall buildings. A girl smiles as she chats excitedly on her cell phone. Men in black suits cluster on a street corner debating their happy hour destination.

item.title: Five things to know: N. Korea threats
item.description: Video propaganda showing the White House and Congress being blown up. Talk of hitting U.S. bases in the Pacific. The renunciation of a 60-year-old armistice that has kept the tenuous peace on the Korean Peninsula.

item.title: Trump sues in 'cybersquatting' claim
item.description: Donald Trump is seeking $400,000 in damages from a Brooklyn man over four websites that use the real estate mogul's name and brand.

item.title: Japanese business sentiment ticks up
item.description: The mood among Japan's biggest companies has brightened three months after prime minister Shinzo Abe went all out to reflate the world's third-largest economy.

item.title: Scramble to get cash out of Cyprus
item.description: The hunt is on to find ways to circumnavigate the new draconian capital controls in Cyprus and get money off the island.

item.title: Emerging markets dump euro reserves
item.description: The euro's challenge to the international status of the US dollar has been set back a generation as new data show developing countries dumping the European currency from their official reserves.

item.title: Detroit airport evacuated in bomb fear
item.description: A terminal at Detroit Metropolitan Airport was evacuated early Monday as explosive teams looked into a suspicious device.

item.title: Oil tanker suicide attack kills nine in Iraq
item.description: A suicide bomber drove an oil tanker into a police station in central Tikrit on Monday, killing at least nine people and wounding 20 others, Iraq's interior ministry said.

item.title: Mandela's condition improving: Doctors
item.description: Former South African President Nelson Mandela's condition continues to improve, the country's presidential office said.

item.title: Deadly accident at U.S. nuclear site
item.description: An accident at a nuclear facility in Arkansas killed one person Sunday, a county coroner said.

item.title: 2 dead in China from new bird flu strain
item.description: Two people in China have died and another remains critical after falling ill with a strain of bird flu not detected before in humans, the official Chinese news agency Xinhua reported.

item.title: Egypt satirist accused of insulting Islam
item.description: An Egyptian TV host who has been compared to Comedy Central's Jon Stewart was released on bail Sunday. Bassem Yousef is accused of insulting Islam and Egyptian President Mohamed Morsy.

item.title: 3 feared dead in rescue helicopter crash
item.description: An Alaska State Trooper helicopter that had been sent to rescue a stranded snowmobiler crashed -- and authorities fear that all three occupants on board are dead.

item.title: Pope calls for peace in key conflicts
item.description: Pope Francis uses his first celebration of Easter Mass as pontiff to urge peace and harmony in the Middle East, Africa and the Korean peninsula.

item.title: Clashes kill 2 after Kenyan poll verdict
item.description: Two people died in clashes in western Kenya after the top court in the nation upheld Uhuru Kenyatta's victory in the presidential election.

item.title: Man with first U.S. face transplant weds
item.description: Horrific events brought them together.

item.title: Who is killing prosecutors in Texas?
item.description: A Texas community is on edge after a district attorney who said he would put away the "scum" who killed a colleague two months ago was shot to death alongside his wife in his home Saturday night.

item.title: 3 killed in 75-car pileup in U.S.
item.description: Three people were killed and dozens were injured in a 75-car pileup on a highway in Virginia Sunday, police said.

item.title: Saudi Arabia may block messaging apps
item.description: Saudi Arabia may block access to popular Internet messaging applications like Skype, Viber and WhatsApp if telecommunication providers there don't comply with rules and regulatory conditions, according to the country's official news agency, SPA.

item.title: Man plows car into Walmart
item.description: A man plowed a car through the front doors of a Walmart store in California Sunday, then attacked customers with a blunt object, police said.

item.title: Rapist recaptured after 35 years
item.description: Convicted serial rapist Gary Irving was offered a weekend of freedom by a judge in Massachusetts before reporting to jail. He took nearly 35 years.

item.title: 1962's 'Playmate of the Year' dies
item.description: Playboy magazine's 1962 "Playmate of the Year," Christa Speck Krofft, died March 22 of natural causes at the age of 70, a family spokesman said Friday.

item.title: Tracking huge great white shark
item.description: Here's a view from aboard a fishing boat of what it's like to nab and tag a great white shark for research purposes.

item.title: Becker: Ronaldo the tennis ace?
item.description: Cristiano Ronaldo has the perfect physique for tennis, according to tennis great Boris Becker.

item.title: 'Miniature TV' in your tummy
item.description: PillCam is a ingestible video camera with a transmitter which lets doctors look inside your digestive tract.

item.title: The man behind 'Lara Croft'
item.description: Ian Livingstone is a legend in the fantasy games world. In 1995, he stumbled upon "Lara Croft" and the rest is history.

item.title: Rodman: Kim Jong Un 'my friend'
item.description: Ato Boldon, Politico's Ben Smith and Reihan Salam discuss criticism over Dennis Rodman's trip to North Korea.

item.title: Marcel Desailly's Ghana regret
item.description: French World Cup winning defender Marcel Desailly tells CNN that he would have loved to play for Ghana at least once.

item.title: 'Batman' helps UK police
item.description: A costumed crusader brought in a man wanted for burglary.

item.title: Go inside a sinkhole
item.description: Ever wonder what a sinkhole looks like on the inside? CNN's David Mattingly dives in for a peek in Florida.

item.title: Top scientist aims to 'repair the brain'
item.description: Ed Boyden is only 33, but he's already helped invent influential technologies in the study of the human brain.

item.title: Is this an abduction or a hoax?
item.description: The NYPD is searching for three suspects possibly involved with attempted abduction in the Washington Heights area.

item.title: Egypt's Jon Stewart quizzed by govt.
item.description: Egypt calls popular political satirist for questioning. CNN's Ian Lee reports.

item.title: What it's like to have a killer in the family
item.description: "Missy, you need to change your last name," the shackled man in the orange prison jumpsuit said into the receiver, staring blankly at his 15-year-old daughter's tear-stained face.

item.title: Rare appearance for Turin Shroud
item.description: As Christians mark Easter weekend, what may be the most famous religious relic of them all, the Turin Shroud, will make a rare TV appearance.

item.title: Polar bear cub frolicks around zoo
item.description: The Buffalo Zoo in New York debuted its newest polar bear cub, Luna.

item.title: Marilyn Monroe's letter: I'm going crazy
item.description: Notes from actress Marilyn Monroe and other notables could bring in millions of dollars. CNN's Brooke Baldwin has more.

item.title: Pakistan cricket idol now political force
item.description: Pakistan's upcoming election could signal a change in the political status quo. CNN's Nic Robertson reports.

item.title: 'Walking Dead' cast, crew spill their guts
item.description: "The Walking Dead" fans always fill CNN.com's comments sections and iReport with questions and observations about TV's hottest show.

item.title: Behind the North Korean veil
item.description: North Korean rhetoric has reached fever pitch with new threats aimed at their neighbors and the U.S. But last year, photographer Olaf Schuelker gained a rare glimpse at life inside the secretive country.

item.title: New pope, new legacy
item.description: CNN's Jim Bittermann reports on how the new pope already is distinguishing himself from his predecessor.

item.title: Oprah: Being a brand is difficult
item.description: OWN Chairman and CEO Oprah Winfrey on the challenges and responsibilities associated with being a brand.

item.title: Turning old nets into energy
item.description: Hawaii turns derelict fishing nets into electricity. CNN's Kyung Lah explains.

item.title: Were you like this at 17?
item.description: Silicon Valley giant Yahoo is turning to a 17-year-old to boost the company's mobile development by acquiring the teenager's tech start-up in a reported multi-million dollar deal.

item.title: Secret world of the super slo-mo
item.description: A BYU facility has received attention for their extraordinary videos of ordinary actions into slow motion.

item.title: Pakistani women teaching in fear
item.description: Nic Robertson reports on a teacher who lives in fear but refuses to be intimidated

item.title: Man who took a bullet for Reagan
item.description: A former Secret Service agent who took a bullet intended for President Ronald Reagan talks about his experience.

item.title: Shooter sorry for pyramid photos
item.description: Was it the ultimate adventure or an audacious act of disrespect that should be punished by law?

item.title: 5 twists on Spring Cleaning
item.description: Do you grow vegetables from your windows or convert urine to fertilizer? Explore these and other innovative ideas to make better use of resources.

item.title: McIlroy: Why I skipped Haiti
item.description: Rory McIlroy has apologized after putting his need for more competitive golf action ahead of a planned humanitarian visit to Haiti next week -- and said his caddy had played a big part in the decision.

item.title: Why Knox case is so complicated
item.description: Amanda Knox and Raffaele Sollecito are told to face an Italian court again for the murder of Meredith Kercher. CNN investigates why.

item.title: Pop innovator Ramone dies at 79
item.description: Innovative music producer Phil Ramone, whose work with the major artists of the modern era won him 14 Grammys and prompted the nickname "Pope of Pop," died Saturday morning in a New York hospital, his son, Matt, told CNN.

item.title: Humans care for rejected gorilla
item.description: A mom rejected her baby gorilla, so human surrogates are raising Gladys at the Cincinnati Zoo until they find a new mom.

item.title: Easter by the numbers
item.description: Some Christians will mark the resurrection of Jesus Christ on Easter by donning their Sunday best, attending church and going on egg hunts. But what's the history of the holiday? And how much will we actually spend on those yummy chocolate rabbits? Below are some interesting facts about Easter:

item.title: St. Petersburg's best sights
item.description: Sometimes called the Paris of the East, St. Petersburg showcases a spectacular history from tsarist Russia to the present.

item.title: Top scientist aims to 'repair the brain'
item.description: Ed Boyden is only 33, but he's already helped invent influential technologies in the study of the human brain.

item.title: Mapping the human brain
item.description: Ten years after the Human Genome Project was completed, researchers are turning their focus to mapping the human brain.

item.title: EXCLUSIVE: Inside an Afghan firefight
item.description: Watch as U.S. Special Forces in Afghanistan run into battle as they hunt down Taliban forces in an area known as a playground for insurgency. CNN's Anna Coren reports from the firefight.

item.title: War drums of N. Korea don't echo in South
item.description: While Pyongyang state television marches to a military drum beat, citizens and tourists in Seoul seem immune to North Korea's warlike rhetoric.

item.title: Life goes on in South Korea
item.description: As winter recedes, winds whip through downtown Seoul and chill the crowds of commuters on their way home. The sun is dropping and the pale golden light streams between tall buildings. A girl smiles as she chats excitedly on her cell phone. Men in black suits cluster on a street corner debating their happy hour destination.

item.title: Nelson Mandela's health
item.description: Former South African President Nelson Mandela's condition continues to improve, the country's presidential office said.

item.title: Korean tensions rise
item.description: The South Korean president on Monday warned North Korea that any provocative moves will be met with "a strong response" as the United States deployed stealth fighter jets in the tense region as part of joint military exercises.

item.title: Turin Shroud revealed
item.description: What may be the most famous religious relic of them all, the Turin Shroud, will make a rare appearance on Easter Saturday -- on Italians' TV screens.

item.title: Reef's beauty captured on film
item.description: Doing for our oceans what Google Street View has done on land, a team of marine scientists is building up an extraordinary picture of the world's coral reefs.

item.title: Oceans on brink of collapse
item.description: As the human footprint has spread, the remaining wildernesses on our planet have retreated. However, dive just a few meters below the ocean surface and you will enter a world where humans very rarely venture.

item.title: Our Oceans: Victim or savior?
item.description: My grandfather Jacques Cousteau and my father Philippe dedicated their lives to revealing the ocean's wonders and helping us understand our connection to this vast expanse of water. Their work inspired generations and filled people with awe.

item.title: Modeling Earth's ecosystems
item.description: A group of researchers is building a comprehensive model of the Earth's ecosystems to help predict climate change.

item.title: Robots probe ocean depths
item.description: Despite most humans' land-centric view, Earth is an ocean planet. The global ocean covers more than two-thirds of our planet's surface and makes life as we know it possible: it produces half of the oxygen we breathe, helps regulate our climate and provides the single largest habitat for life on Earth.

item.title: Global warming increases pollen
item.description: With global warming, temperature extremes are becoming a norm -- and that's bad news for allergy sufferers.

item.title: World rejects polar bear plan
item.description: A U.S. plan to give new protection to polar bears was voted down Thursday at an international conference on endangered species.

item.title: Study warns global warming 'epic'
item.description: Global warming has propelled Earth's climate from one of its coldest decades since the last ice age to one of its hottest -- in just one century.

item.title: Environmentalists fill U.S. National Mall
item.description: Marching, dancing and poster-waving environmentalists chanting "Hey, Obama. We don't want no climate drama," packed several blocks on and around Washington's National Mall on Sunday, hoping to spur President Barack Obama to take strong measures against climate change.

item.title: China media blasts 'arrogant' Apple
item.description: State-run media in China has lambasted Apple Inc. for "unparalleled arrogance" over alleged complaints about customer service in China.

item.title: 1000+ dead ducks in Chinese River
item.description: Around 1,000 duck carcasses have been found in a river in southwest China, CNN's David McKenzie has more.

item.title: Deft driver dodges decapitation
item.description: A driver in China is recovering from minor injuries after a light pole smashed through the windshield of his bus.

item.title: Vera Wang drops $500 China try-on fee
item.description: U.S. luxury bridal designer Vera Wang's first store in China has gotten off to an unfashionable start. Amid cries of discrimination, the company announced Wednesday it would scrap a controversial policy of charging customers a nearly $500 fee to try on clothes.

item.title: Jack Ma: I'm 'too old' for Internet
item.description: Chinese entrepreneur Jack Ma, who is 48, says he's too old for the Internet.

item.title: Tea, tradition and trade in China
item.description: Growing taste for Pu'er tea is boosting local economy. CNN's Steven Jiang reports.

item.title: China sentences 20 on terror charges
item.description: Two courts in northwest China's Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region sentenced 20 people for alleged terrorist and separatist activities on Tuesday, a spokesperson at the Kashagar Prefecture Intermediate People's Court told CNN.

item.title: China's glamorous First Lady
item.description: China's new First Lady is poised to impress--and burnish China's image overseas.
